subject: Re: [junit] Eclipse - JUnit Configuration?
msgSnippet: That doesn t look like an external address.  It looks like it s trying to access your local port #5254.  Are you running in debug mode? ... -- Jason Rogers
messageBody:
That doesn't look like an external address. It looks like it's trying
to access your local port #5254. Are you running in debug mode?

On Sat, 2004-04-24 at 21:53, Clark I Anderson wrote:
> I am trying to learn JAVA coding with Eclipse and JUnit.
>
> I have started with a couple of small example projects.
>
> I must have created some installation or configuration error???
>
> I have setup a PC as a development machine running Win2000.
> I have installed:
> JDK 1.4.2
> ANT 1.6.1
> Eclipse 2.1.3 (this also happened with 2.1.2)
> JUnit 3.8.1
>
> This PC is on my LAN, but I have not granted permissions for it to
> access my DSL Modem (Zone Alarm).
>
> When I try running JUnit from within Eclipse, it tries to access an
> external IP, which I prevent, and it fails:
>
> Could not connect to: : 5254
> java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused: connect
> at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.socketConnect(Native Method)
> at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.doConnect(Unknown Source)
> at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.connectToAddress(Unknown Source)
> at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.connect(Unknown Source)
> at java.net.Socket.connect(Unknown Source)
> at java.net.Socket.connect(Unknown Source)
> at java.net.Socket.<init>(Unknown Source)
> at java.net.Socket.<init>(Unknown Source)
> at
> org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.connect(RemoteTestRunner.java:547)
> at
> org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.run(RemoteTestRunner.java:270)
> at
> org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.main(RemoteTestRunner.java:167)
>
>
> I do not know why it is trying to use RemoteTestRunner.
>
> I will appreciate guidance.
>
> Clark Anderson
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
--
Jason Rogers

"Where there is no vision, the people perish..."
Bible, Proverbs 29:18
